questions.text: Following section of a peripheral nerve, Schwann cells are responsible for all of the following except:

questions.text: Destruction of the lateral spinothalamic tract at C3 is most likely to result in which one of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Demyelination of fibers in the area that lies in the postolivary lateral aspect of the medulla.

options.label: B
options.text: Damage to cell bodies in the ipsilateral posterior gray horn below the level of the lesion.

options.label: C
options.text: Damage to cell bodies of the ipsilateral VPL thalamic nucleus.

options.label: D
options.text: Damage to cell bodies in the contralateral dorsal root ganglia below the level of the lesion.

questions.correct_answer: A. Demyelination of fibers in the area that lies in the postolivary lateral aspect of the medulla.

questions.text: Which of the following changes can be excepted after the decline in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) from 100 to 50ml/min., when compared with the patient’s condition before the loss of kidney function?

options.label: A
options.text: A 50% decrease in urinary creatinine clearance and a 50% decrease in urinary creatinine excretion

options.label: B
options.text: A 50% reduction in urinary creatinine excretion

options.label: C
options.text: A doubling of plasma creatinine concentration and a 50% decrease in creatinine clearance.

options.label: D
options.text: A doubling of plasma creatinine concentration a 50% decrease in creatinine clearance and a 50% reduction in urinary creatinine excretion.

questions.correct_answer: C. A doubling of plasma creatinine concentration and a 50% decrease in creatinine clearance.

questions.text: Vitamin B12 or folic acid deficiency causes:

questions.text: A 65-year-old male is on a short ladder changing a light and suddenly collapses. He is unresponsive. What is the next step?

67 years old presents with sudden onset dyspnoea and chest pain, study the given image and comment on most appropriate diagnosis: Pulmonary embolism. There is a large filling defect (white arrows) in the right pulmonary artery representing clot. This is a case of pulmonary artery embolism. And this embolism is known as saddle thrombo embolism Radiographic features Plain radiograph Chest radiographic signs include: Fleischner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery(20%) Hampton hump: peripheral wedge of airspace opacity and implies lung infraction(20%) Westermark sign: regional oligemia and highest positive protective value(10%) Pleural effusion(35%) Knuckle sign Palla sign: enlarged right descending pulmonary artery Chang sign: dilated right descending pulmonary artery with sudden cut-off CT Acute pulmonary emboli CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA) will show filling defects within the pulmonary vasculature with acute pulmonary emboli. When the artery is viewed in its axial plane the central filling defect from the thrombus is surrounded by a thin rim of contrast, which has been called the polo mint sign. Emboli may be occlusive or non-occlusive, the latter as seen with a thin stream of contrast adjacent emboli. The affected vessel may also enlarge.

A 70 year-old man with urinary frequency and urge incontinence is referred to the urology outpatient clinc. On digital rectal examination, his prostate is enlarged and the serum prostate specific antigen (PSA) level is elevated. What is the most likely finding on IVU?

options.label: A
options.text: A beaded appearance of the distal urethra

options.label: B
options.text: A smooth rounded filling defect at the dome of the bladder

options.label: C
options.text: J-shaped (‘fish-hook’) appearance of the distal ureters

options.label: D
options.text: Inferior displacement of the ureters by the prostate

questions.correct_answer: C. J-shaped (‘fish-hook’) appearance of the distal ureters
